qas.question: The complexity of problems often depends on what?

answers.text: the type of reduction being used
the type of reduction being used

qas.question: What would create a conflict between a problem X and problem C within the context of reduction?

answers.text: if every problem in C can be reduced to X
problem in C is harder than X

qas.question: An algorithm for X which reduces to C would us to do what?
A problem set that that is hard for the expression NP can also be stated how?

plausible_answers.text: the type of reduction being used.

qas.question: What does the complexity of problems not often depend on?

plausible_answers.text: if every problem in C can be reduced to X

qas.question: What would not create a conflict between a problem X and problem C within the context of reduction?
What problem in C is harder than X?
How is a problem set that is hard for expression QP be stated?

context: This motivates the concept of a problem being hard for a complexity class. A problem X is hard for a class of problems C <a1_0><b5_0>if every problem in C can be reduced to X<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Thus <b6_0>no <a1_1>problem<b6_0/> in C is harder than X<a1_1/>, since an algorithm for X allows us to <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>solve any problem in C<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. Of course, the notion of hard problems depends on <a0_0><a0_1><b4_0>the type of reduction being used<a0_1/><a0_0/>.<b4_0/> For complexity classes larger than P, polynomial-time reductions are commonly used. In particular, the set of problems that are hard for NP is the set of <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b7_0>NP-hard<b7_0/><a3_1/><a3_0/> problems<a3_2/>.
